verse: Three days after arriving in the province, Festus traveled south from Caesarea to Jerusalem.

The chief priests and Jewish leaders still had a plan to kill Paul and gave a report to Festus about their unresolved grievances against Paul. They suggested that as a favor to them, Festus should move Paul to Jerusalem. Of course, this was part of the plan to set an ambush for Paul and kill him en route.
Festus instead offered to reopen the case. He would be going back to Caesarea soon.
Eight or ten days later, Festus returned to Caesarea, and the next day he took his seat in court. He ordered Paul to be brought before him.
The Jewish opponents from Jerusalem immediately surrounded Paul and from all directions bombarded him with all sorts of serious charges, none of which could be proven.
Here Festus saw an opportunity to do just the favor Paul’s Jewish opponents had requested.
Festus conferred privately with his council and returned with this decision:
Several days later, the provincial king Agrippa arrived in Caesarea with his wife Bernice to welcome the new governor.
Their visit lasted several days, which gave Festus the chance to describe Paul’s case to the king.

The next day, King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at the great hall with great formality, accompanied by the military commanders and the city’s leading men. Festus ordered Paul to be brought before them.
